s.text: Here's an architecture (in the sense I mean the term) that was added to the Web by an innovation of Netscape Corporation.
I love the fact that Amazon knows who I am and can recommend books to me when I come to their home page (they've yet to recommend my book to me, but I'm sure they'll get around to that soon enough).
I love the fact that Amazon knows who I am and can recommend books to me when I come to their home page (they've yet to recommend my book to me, but I'm sure they'll get around to that soon enough).
I love the fact that Amazon knows who I am and can recommend books to me when I come to their home page (they've yet to recommend my book to me, but I'm sure they'll get around to that soon enough).
And it has that power because its network has been architected to give it that power.
And that we ought to pay attention to the influences that are changing this architecture, and therefore changing this freedom.
And that we ought to pay attention to the influences that are changing this architecture, and therefore changing this freedom.
And that we ought to pay attention to the influences that are changing this architecture, and therefore changing this freedom.
It has been architected, that is, to be different from the principle of non-discrimination in the original Net.
The libertarian would talk about externalities, and about minimum regulation to avoid externalities, and about the value of common carriers, and the like.
And more important, slow to see how much of the freedom they enjoy comes not (just) from the absence of government, but also from a constitution of freedom built into the architecture of the Net.
